title: How to Throw a Cylinder

steps.headline: Make yourself comfortable.
steps.description: Sit with your legs spread wide so that you can rest your elbows on the inside of your thighs. This is to allow more pressure to come from your entire body onto the piece rather than just your hands.

steps.headline: Slam a round ball of clay as close to the center of the wheel as possible.
steps.description: This serves two purposes, one so that the clay will stick well to the wheel and also to eliminate air bubbles that are in the clay.

steps.headline: Start the wheel and allow it to spin slowly.
steps.description: As the wheel is turning dampen your hands and get the ball wet as well. Then start patting the ball into a cone shame until it is no longer wobbling.

steps.headline: Place your hands on the cone only after the wheel is going at a medium pace.
steps.description: Again force the clay into the center of the wheel. If you are right handed your left elbow should dig into your left thigh. Your entire body is used to center the piece.

steps.headline: While pressing down with the thumb into the center of the piece, use your other hand to guide your thumb into the piece.
steps.description: Press your arms into your side to keep your arms from moving. Leave enough clay on the bottom of the piece so that you will be able to have a bottom.

steps.headline: Use both of your hands to widen the hole established.
steps.description: When water builds up on the bottom of the cylinder use a dry sponge to soak up the excess water.

steps.headline: Squeeze the walls up by placing your index finger of your left hand on the inside while your right index finger is on the outside.
steps.description: This is called pulling, be careful not to puncture the clay, however apply enough force so that clay is being forced upwards. How fast you pull up on the piece is affected by how fast the wheel is moving. Therefore the quicker the wheel is spinning the faster you can finish a piece. It is better to not go fast when you are first starting out, once you feel more comfortable with the motions you will be able to go faster.

steps.headline: Repeat pulling until the walls of the cylinder are thick enough for you, which is about a quarter of an inch thick.
steps.description: If there is a large amount of clay around the base of the piece then trim the base of the piece with a wooden tool that is cut at a 45 degree angle.

steps.headline: Cup a moderately wet sponge around the top edge of the piece and apply slight pressure to make the edge rounded and more appealing.
Slowly slide a wire underneath your piece while the wheel is moving at a slow pace.
steps.description: Careful not to go through the bottom of your piece. Make sure that the wire hugs the wheel tightly.
